text: Eric come I'd fix us is a federal
interpreter who helped translate for the
cases of nearly 400 illegal immigrants
arrested in May at an Iowa meatpacking
plant it was the largest criminal
enforcement operation ever carried out
by immigration authorities at a
workplace
mr. Kamiya fix us is speaking publicly
for the first time about his experience
what was striking was to see these
people enter and basically you know
they're shackled at their feet their
wrists and the wrists are shackled to
their waist so chains and so they can
only take few little steps very short
little steps and the chains are dragging
on the floor so it makes a terrible
impression then you see that they are
all about five feet tall and and you
start when they start calling their name
you start recognizing Mayan names last
names so the there was a real racial
contrast between the detainees in Chains
and the rest of the court with this
grandeur they were being charged well
with Social Security fraud using a full
Social Security number but what struck
me was that they were also being charged
with aggravated identity theft and that
just seemed awkward it didn't fit many
of the people we interviewed didn't know
what a social security number was or
what it's used for and they you could
tell they were telling the truth because
they would say it was shame you know
like they didn't want to appear ignorant
but you would ask him what is this
number here
I don't know and who put it there both
like the factory they are the plant they
just filled it out for me because you
know
I just don't know the language the truth
of the matter is that many of them
couldn't read or write Spanish let alone
English so and one of the elements of
the offense of Social Security fraud is
knowingly so there was a pretty good
indication that many of them were
actually not guilty yet they had no
choice but to plead up you know it's an
uncomfortable situation because we are
not supposed to show any emotion or any
indication of preference or favoritism
or bias and we're not supposed to be
commenting what's going on so everybody
was going about their business everybody
was doing their duty but there was a
somber aspect to it a certain heavy
heartedness after the arraignments the
initial appearances they were sent to
jail we went with the defense attorneys
to meet individually with them in jail
and explained the plea agreement that
the government was offering it worked
like this basically if you plead guilty
to using knowingly using a full social
security number the government will
withdraw the heavier charge of identity
theft and you would have to serve five
months in jail before being deported if
you pleaded not guilty it could take six
to eight months waiting for a trial and
since these people were under an
immigration detainer they have no right
of bail so basically even if they felt
they were not guilty they
if they pleaded not guilty it meant
waiting six to eight months in jail for
a trial and then a trial they always
stood the risk of losing and then if
they lost they were facing at a minimum
of two years in prison they were begging
to be deported they had families whether
in Iowa or many of them back in their
countries who depended on them they were
the sole owners I remember one case it
was a 19 year old young man he was the
only one in his family who got sent out
to work he was the only provider for his
family his parents were too old to work
so they sent him to basically risk it
and get across the border and so forth
so he was worried sick
I don't want it happening again I don't
want it to happen again as a citizen I
have the right of speech which I think
takes precedence over everything else
and so far my colleagues have supported
me and I hope that many other people
will as well I have tremendous respect
for the men and women of Immigration and
Customs Enforcement these people do you
know a very honorable job they are my
colleagues when I'm in the legal system
they are my coworkers they're doing
their job and the problem is like many
people have said our system is broken
well in this case these agencies have
been given way too much power by
Congress a power that was designed to
fight the war on terror and which now
they are using to fight the war on
illegal immigration
